intro: Geranium robertianum var. minutiflorum, commonly known as the lesser geranium or mouse-ear geranium, is a small, herbaceous perennial native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of about 10–20 cm, featuring basal leaves that are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of tiny, pink or red flowers in late spring to early summer, which are borne on slender, erect stems. Its flowers have five petals and are often accompanied by five sepals, giving it a delicate appearance. This species is often found in moist, shaded areas such as woodlands and stream banks.
